defs.docs: Async interface for working with processes.

attributes.value: / Async interface for working with processes.
/ This crate is an async version of [`std::process`].
/ A background thread named "async-process" is lazily created on first use, which waits for
/ spawned child processes to exit and then calls the `wait()` syscall to clean up the "zombie"
/ processes. This is unlike the `process` API in the standard library, where dropping a running
/ This crate uses [`async-io`] for async I/O on Unix-like systems and [`blocking`] for async I/O
/ Spawn a process and collect its output:
/ Read the output line-by-line as it gets produced:

defs.docs: Unix-specific extensions.

defs.name: CommandExt

defs.name: uid
defs.value: pub fn uid(&mut Self, u32) -> &mut Command
defs.docs:
Sets the child process's user ID. This translates to a
 `setuid` call in the child process. Failure in the `setuid`
 call will cause the spawn to fail.

attributes.value: / Sets the child process's user ID. This translates to a
/ `setuid` call in the child process. Failure in the `setuid`
/ call will cause the spawn to fail.

defs.name: gid
defs.value: pub fn gid(&mut Self, u32) -> &mut Command
defs.docs:
Similar to `uid`, but sets the group ID of the child process. This has
 the same semantics as the `uid` field.

attributes.value: / Similar to `uid`, but sets the group ID of the child process. This has
/ the same semantics as the `uid` field.

defs.name: pre_exec
defs.value:
pub unsafe fn pre_exec<F>(&mut Self, F) -> &mut Command where F: FnMut() ->
io::Result<()> + Send + Sync + 'static
defs.docs:
Schedules a closure to be run just before the `exec` function is
 invoked.

attributes.value: / Schedules a closure to be run just before the `exec` function is
/ The closure is allowed to return an I/O error whose OS error code will
/ be communicated back to the parent and returned as an error from when
/ Multiple closures can be registered and they will be called in order of
/ their registration. If a closure returns `Err` then no further closures
/ will be called and the spawn operation will immediately return with a
/ This closure will be run in the context of the child process after a
/ `fork`. This primarily means that any modifications made to memory on
/ behalf of this closure will **not** be visible to the parent process.
/ This is often a very constrained environment where normal operations
/ like `malloc` or acquiring a mutex are not guaranteed to work (due to
/ other threads perhaps still running when the `fork` was run).
/ This also means that all resources such as file descriptors and
/ memory-mapped regions got duplicated. It is your responsibility to make
/ sure that the closure does not violate library invariants by making
/ When this closure is run, aspects such as the stdio file descriptors and
/ working directory have successfully been changed, so output to these
/ locations may not appear where intended.

defs.name: exec
defs.docs:
Performs all the required setup by this `Command`, followed by calling
 the `execvp` syscall.

attributes.value: / Performs all the required setup by this `Command`, followed by calling
/ On success this function will not return, and otherwise it will return
/ an error indicating why the exec (or another part of the setup of the
/ `exec` not returning has the same implications as calling
/ [`std::process::exit`] – no destructors on the current stack or any other
/ thread’s stack will be run. Therefore, it is recommended to only call
/ `exec` at a point where it is fine to not run any destructors. Note,
/ that the `execvp` syscall independently guarantees that all memory is
/ freed and all file descriptors with the `CLOEXEC` option (set by default
/ on all file descriptors opened by the standard library) are closed.
/ This function, unlike `spawn`, will **not** `fork` the process to create
/ a new child. Like spawn, however, the default behavior for the stdio
/ descriptors will be to inherited from the current process.
/ The process may be in a "broken state" if this function returns in
/ error. For example the working directory, environment variables, signal
/ handling settings, various user/group information, or aspects of stdio
/ file descriptors may have changed. If a "transactional spawn" is
/ required to gracefully handle errors it is recommended to use the

defs.name: Child
defs.docs: A spawned child process.

attributes.value: / The process can be in running or exited state. Use [`status()`][`Child::status()`] or
/ [`output()`][`Child::output()`] to wait for it to exit.
/ If the [`Child`] is dropped, the process keeps running in the background.

defs.name: kill
defs.docs: Forces the child process to exit.

attributes.value: / Forces the child process to exit.
/ If the child has already exited, an [`InvalidInput`] error is returned.
/ This is equivalent to sending a SIGKILL on Unix platforms.

defs.name: try_status
defs.docs: Returns the exit status if the process has exited.

attributes.value: / Returns the exit status if the process has exited.
/ Unlike [`status()`][`Child::status()`], this method will not drop the stdin handle.

defs.name: status
defs.docs: Drops the stdin handle and waits for the process to exit.

defs.name: ChildStdin
defs.docs: A handle to a child process's standard input (stdin).

attributes.value: / A handle to a child process's standard input (stdin).
/ When a [`ChildStdin`] is dropped, the underlying handle gets clossed. If the child process was
/ previously blocked on input, it becomes unblocked after dropping.

defs.name: ChildStdout
defs.docs: A handle to a child process's standard output (stdout).

attributes.value: / A handle to a child process's standard output (stdout).
/ When a [`ChildStdout`] is dropped, the underlying handle gets closed.

defs.name: ChildStderr
defs.docs: A handle to a child process's standard error (stderr).

attributes.value: / A handle to a child process's standard error (stderr).

defs.name: reap_on_drop
defs.value: pub fn reap_on_drop(&mut Self, bool) -> &mut Command
defs.docs: Configures whether to reap the zombie process when [`Child`] is dropped.

attributes.value: / Configures whether to reap the zombie process when [`Child`] is dropped.
/ When the process finishes, it becomes a "zombie" and some resources associated with it
/ If its exit code is never collected, the resources may leak forever. This crate has a
/ background thread named "async-process" that collects such "zombie" processes and then
/ "reaps" them, thus preventing the resource leaks.
/ The default value of this option is `true`.

defs.name: kill_on_drop
defs.value: pub fn kill_on_drop(&mut Self, bool) -> &mut Command
defs.docs: Configures whether to kill the process when [`Child`] is dropped.

attributes.value: / Configures whether to kill the process when [`Child`] is dropped.
/ The default value of this option is `false`.

defs.name: spawn
defs.docs: Executes the command and returns the [`Child`] handle to it.

attributes.value: / Executes the command and returns the [`Child`] handle to it.
/ If not configured, stdin, stdout and stderr will be set to [`Stdio::inherit()`].
/ After spawning the process, stdin, stdout, and stderr become unconfigured again.

defs.name: status
defs.docs: Executes the command, waits for it to exit, and returns the exit status.

attributes.value: / Executes the command, waits for it to exit, and returns the exit status.
/ If not configured, stdin, stdout and stderr will be set to [`Stdio::inherit()`].
/ After spawning the process, stdin, stdout, and stderr become unconfigured again.

defs.name: output
defs.docs: Executes the command and collects its output.

/ If not configured, stdin will be set to [`Stdio::null()`], and stdout and stderr will be
/ After spawning the process, stdin, stdout, and stderr become unconfigured again.
